keyTakeAways: A fuel tanker overturned and exploded in Niger State, Nigeria, killing at least 35 people.
The crash occurred when the tanker was transporting petrol from Lagos to northern Nigeria.
The vehicle skidded off the road, spilled petrol, which ignited shortly after the crash.
The Federal Road Safety Corps (FRSC) confirmed the incident and reported that several people were injured, with severe burns reported.
Niger State Governor Mohammed Umaru Bago expressed condolences and stated that people approached the overturned tanker to retrieve its contents, which increased exposure to danger.

Farouk Mohammed Kawo, chairman of the Niger State tanker drivers’ association, described the incident as 'devastating and avoidable' and blamed the deplorable state of the roads for the high accident rate.
A lack of pipeline infrastructure in Nigeria means that fossil fuels are transported primarily by road, contributing to frequent accidents.
Poorly maintained roads with potholes are a significant factor in road accidents that kill dozens annually in Nigeria.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fuel tanker transporting petrol from Lagos to Niger State crashed and exploded in the Katcha local government area of Essa, killing at least 35 people and injuring many others with severe burns. The Federal Road Safety Corps confirmed the incident, while local officials, including Governor Mohammed Umaru Bago and his press secretary Bologi Ibrahim, expressed deep condolences and highlighted the dangerous behavior of people approaching the overturned tanker to retrieve fuel. The tanker drivers’ association chairman, Farouk Mohammed Kawo, described the tragedy as avoidable and blamed poor road conditions, including potholes and a lack of pipeline infrastructure, which forces fossil fuel transport via road. This incident reflects a broader pattern of deadly accidents in Nigeria, where deteriorating road conditions and inadequate transport infrastructure contribute to frequent and fatal crashes.
title: Nigerian fuel tanker explosion kills 35, road safety agency says
